articles.title: JANUARY 1985
articles.summary: The January 1985 schedule details various astronomical activities, including indoor star parties, board meetings, and a field expedition. A key event is the January 28th general meeting featuring Bob Fingerhut and Ron Walton, who will present a slide narration on their "South Pacific Total Solar Eclipse Expedition," showcasing rare photos of the solar corona. The document also lists early February events, including an annual civil evening at Henry Coe State Park, celebrating its reopening.

articles.title: ASTROPHOTOGRAPHY SEMINAR IN MARCH
articles.summary: The Sixth annual ASTROPHOTO VI SEMINAR for amateur astrophotographers is scheduled for Saturday, March 2, 1985, at California State University at Fullerton. Sponsored by the Orange County Astronomers and other societies, the event will include papers, displays, an international astrophotography exhibition with cash prizes, and seminar proceedings. Papers were solicited with a February 1 deadline.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article announces recent comet discoveries, including Comet Levy-Rudenko (1984t) by amateur astronomers David Levy and Michael Rudenko, and Comet Hartley (1984v) by Malcolm Hartley. It provides details on Levy-Rudenko's visibility and discovery circumstances, highlighting the dedication of the amateur discoverers. Additionally, the piece reviews the historical features of the "Comet Comments" column, preparing for a new special section.

articles.title: DATE R. A. (1950) Dec. Elon6. Mag.
articles.summary: This article presents ephemeris data for three comets: Comet Levy-Rudenko (1984t), Comet Shoemaker (1984s), and Periodic Comet Schaumasse (1984m), covering dates from late December through early February. For each comet, it provides celestial coordinates (R.A., Dec.), elongation, and magnitude, along with brief observational notes on their visibility, movement, and appearance during this period. The information helps observers locate and identify these comets.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND--HALLEY'S COMET
articles.summary: Despite not holding any records for brightness, tail length, or coma size, Halley's Comet is presented as the most famous comet, renowned for its consistent historical appearances and Edmond Halley's accurate prediction of its return. The article details its recovery in 1982 and tracks its current approach, noting its increasing magnitude and proximity to the Sun, with a promise of future observation guidance.

articles.title: DEEP SKY NOTES - JANUARY
articles.summary: The "Deep Sky Notes - January" article by Steve Gottlieb discusses the historical New General Catalogue (NGC) of deep-sky objects, published by J.L.E. Dreyer in 1888. It highlights that this foundational catalogue, despite its widespread use, contains numerous errors including typos, duplicate entries, and positional inaccuracies. Dreyer himself attempted to correct these issues through addenda and the subsequent publication of two Index Catalogues (IC I and IC II) in 1895 and 1908.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions and logistical information for general meetings held at the University of Santa Clara, specifically in Alumni Science Hall, room 102. It includes driving instructions from both north and south on Hwy 17, parking guidance, and confirms that meetings commence at 8 PM.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES:
articles.summary: The document announces an "INDOOR STAR PARTY" event held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building. It provides detailed driving directions to the venue, located at 18011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd., and states that the event opens at 8 PM.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: Grant Ranch County Park is introduced as a new observing site for the SJAA, located on Mt. Hamilton Road between San Jose and Lick Observatory. The document provides detailed driving directions from various routes and instructs users on how to access the park's locked front gate using the combination 6565.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Henry Coe State Park from Hwy 101 South via the East Dunne exit. It includes specific instructions for accessing the park's observing area, noting a gate combination (6565) and the requirement to park outside and scout a site before driving in, with a reminder to use parking lights only after dark.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, starting from Highway 101 South and navigating through Highway 156 East towards San Juan Bautista. It includes specific turns and advises on road conditions and the use of parking lights after dark within the park. The article also notes that 'EPHEMERIS' is published monthly by the San Jose Astronomical Association.

articles.title: OFFICERS:
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers of an organization, detailing the roles of President, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer. For each officer, their full name, mailing address, and phone number are provided. It serves as a directory for the organization's leadership contact information.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
articles.summary: This document provides a contact list for an organization's key personnel, specifically listing the members of its Board of Directors along with their phone numbers. It also includes the name and mailing address for the Ephemeris Editor. The information serves as a directory for reaching the organization's leadership and editorial staff.

articles.title: THE SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) welcomes individuals with diverse astronomical interests, including deep-sky observing, astrophotography, telescope making, eclipses, and computing. Members can connect with others who share their passions and are eager to share knowledge and experiences. The association aims to foster a collaborative environment for all levels of astronomy enthusiasts.

articles.title: ACTIVITIES
articles.summary: The SJAA hosts various Saturday night activities, excluding holidays, for its members. These include monthly General Meetings at the University of Santa Clara featuring astronomical programs, outdoor 'Star' Parties for group observing at multiple locations, and informal Indoor 'Star Parties' in Los Gatos for sharing slides, working on equipment, and exchanging ideas.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP BENEFITS
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), a non-profit group founded in 1954, offers various benefits for members, though participation in activities is open to all. Membership advantages include a discounted subscription to Sky and Telescope magazine, the monthly SJAA EPHEMERIS newsletter, access to club telescopes, and a library of astronomical resources. The SJAA aims to foster public interest in astronomy, support amateur research, and promote the science, with membership costs ranging from $8.00 to $21.00.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It requests basic personal details such as name, address, and telephone number, and offers options for adult, junior, or bulletin-only membership. The form includes instructions for submission either in person at an SJAA meeting or by mail to the association's treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document is an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about an individual's astronomical interests and experience. It asks about specific interests such as astro-photography or deep-sky observation, whether they own a telescope and its type, and areas where they might be able to offer assistance to others. The survey aims to collect personal data likely for community engagement or membership profiling within an astronomy-related group.

articles.title: Photographic surveys such as the Palomar Observatory Sky Survey (POSS) compiled from 1950-1958 when ephemerides of the National Geographic Society using the 48" Palomar Schmidt camera provided a more reliable check on galaxy identities than were available in The Revised New General Catalogue (RNGC; by Sulentic and Tifft in 1973 used the POSS prints to photographically identify the NGC objects, provide accurate coordinates (epoch 1975 0) and give modern descriptions based on their photographic appearance. In cases where an NGC galaxy from the RNGC was not within 5' radius of the originally published NGC coordinates, the object was labeled "nonexistent" and placed in their Class 7. Unfortunately, the RNGC and other modern catalogues have sometimes been misled in their identifications by previous NGC errors. Occasionally when tracking down NGC errors it is necessary to refer to the original sources to attempt to determine the correct identities.
articles.summary: The article highlights the challenges in accurate galaxy identification, demonstrating how even modern photographic surveys like POSS and catalogs such as RNGC can contain or propagate errors from earlier sources. It presents a detailed case study of a galaxy group in Leo, where significant discrepancies across several modern catalogs necessitated a return to original 19th-century observations, specifically Lord Rosse's 1857 sketch. This historical research ultimately resolved the conflicting identifications and corrected errors in modern astronomical catalogs.

articles.title: FROM THE EDITORS DESK
articles.summary: This editor's desk update clarifies that the Fremont Peak Observatory Association (F.P.O.A.) is a distinct organization collaborating with, not competing against, the SJAA to benefit Bay Area amateur astronomers, while the SJAA progresses with its Grant Ranch observatory project and seeks member feedback. It also announces board nominations, upcoming events like a Henry Coe Park expedition and a solar eclipse presentation, and requests contributions for the bulletin.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This 'Astro Ads' section features a classified advertisement for an 80mm refractor telescope, complete with accessories, available for $350. Additionally, the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is seeking a Program Chairperson to find interesting speakers for its monthly general meetings. The document also provides mailing and bulk rate postage information for the SJAA.
